qas.question: What wsas the satellite internet growth rate as of 2009?
Dalkom Somalia provided internet over what?
Who were one of the main clients of the local satellite service providers?
As broadband access rose, what happened to the demand for satellite services?
What did national bandwidth providers cost?
How many terminals linked to North America?
How many teleports were there in Europe and Asia?
When did Dalkom Somalia begin providing internet over satellite?

context: As of <b8_0>2009<b8_0/>, Internet via <a1_0>satellite<a1_0/> had a steady growth rate of <a0_0>10% to 15% per year<a0_0/>. It was particularly in demand in remote areas that did not have either dialup or wireless online services. The local telecommunications company <b4_0>Dalkom Somalia<b4_0/> provided internet over satellite, as well as premium routes for media operators and content providers, and international voice gateway services for global carriers. It also offered inexpensive bandwidth through its internet backbone, whereas bandwidth ordinarily cost customers from <b5_0>$2,500 to $3,000 per month<b5_0/> through the major international bandwidth providers. The main clients of these local satellite services were <a2_0>internet cafes<a2_0/>, money transfer firms and other companies, as well as international community representatives. In total, there were over <b6_0><b7_0>300<b7_0/><b6_0/> local satellite terminals available aross the nation, which were linked to teleports in Europe and Asia. Demand for the satellite services <a3_0>gradually began to fall<a3_0/> as broadband wireless access rose. However, it increased in rural areas, as the main client base for the satellite services extended their operations into more remote locales.
